name: differed
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
past simple and past participle of
differ
B2 to be not like something or someone else, either physically or in another way: The twins look alike, but they differ in temperament. His views differ considerably from those of his parents. The findings of the various studies differ significantly/markedly/radically. The incidence of the illness differs greatly between men and women.
formal to disagree: Economists differ on the cause of inflation. I beg to differ with you on that point.
More examplesFewer examplesEye-witness accounts of the fighting differ markedly from police reports of what happened.The three birds differ in small features (see Plate 4).It's essentially a dictionary but it differs in one or two respects.This proposal differs from the last one in many important respects.The dispute is based on two widely differing interpretations of the law.
